comment:
however it is important to note.... thats my best descriptor of chatgpt's format
in the beginning stages, thinking about how people will use it initially, i think its in our nature to poke and prod, to see where it aligns the dissemination of data to the users, to see if it is similar to our own personal belief systems. i cant see anything more curious than if the ai is a friend or foe so to speak. then i think the human nature of contesting the intelligence itself, trying to break it with logic puzzles or pushing how much it can process using a variety of techniques, thats something i thnk users are drawn to, is the ai smarter than us. other things i see as we the first massive group of users, finding out if can give us advantages in things that may have been difficult in the past, can i use this chat to race to the front of the class. these things will subside i think, and the googling aspect will settle in eventually. thats because i believe the ai will settle into a state that wont be exploitable or entertain users when desires are nefarious, it will regulate user behavior basically by nonparticipation. if the designer do it right, and not have the ai preach, and just not respond to the no no off limits stuff, it will work way better i think.

comment:
Sam's a rat. As much as I think the word lazy is primarily weaponized against people who are trapped by a bunch of bullshit to handwave away the financial crimes committed against them constantly that keeps them in bad situations, the way Sam, and others in the LLM business, run and sell their companies and products is indicative of the pure, unadulterated laziness that can only be spawned by a bunch of assholes having blank checks handed to them constantly.

LLMs could have been first and foremost turned towards solving a bunch of big and very difficult problems that would have positive material impact on peoples' lives. Things like translation and complex data driven research, put in the hands of people who can and will check the model's work and who are capable of discerning where or not what its giving them is valuable. But that would be much harder, and much less profitable to him and people like him with a big financial stake in the game.

Instead he looked at the potential to profit and that tech has been pointed specifically towards typical bullshit "disruption" of existing markets and workforces, which always results in tax payer money in rich peoples' pockets and worse experiences for normal people. And what do we have for that? A bunch of complex auto-complete systems shitting out lies constantly being falsely sold as "artificial intelligence", all of them based on data that was harvested without consent or much in the way of concern for quality or content. The only thing Sam's done is turn a bunch of stuff people have done with no expectation of generating profit or being profited off of into a revenue stream.

He hasn't revolutionized anything. He's just walked into a metaphorical public park, dug up all the flowers when no one was looking, and rolled up to the flea market to sell them back. The only thing only effect his non-tools that he calls AI are capable of achieving is the displacing of people financially for the benefit of large corporations. Just like Uber and Doordash displaced delivery and taxi drivers, and Amazon and Walmart displaced small local business before them. Worse lives for a bunch of people so that Sam Altman and everyone riding his coattails can get in on the same grift that every other startup has attempted to pull over the last decade.

The same variety of fetid VC con, but someone's glued some wires to the outside of the box this time and convinced a bunch of losers its then next big thing. "Waah, we're misunderstood." Nah, asshole, people understand plenty. They understand that what you're trying to do is make a bunch of normal peoples' lives harder so you can make a quick buck. They understand that you don't give a damn if your "tools", which is a generous descriptor for them, do incalculable damage to the lives and livelihoods of people who aren't you as long as you cover your ass in regards to ones who are an actual financial threat to you - i.e. celebrities and politicians. Zero interest in turning these endeavors towards actually productive ends, as long as you can sit around like every other hollowed out tech ghoul and dismiss criticism with the classic "if we didn't do it some worse would" line, like you aren't the someone worse for deploying these systems like this in the first place.

Man's got a black pit at the core of his soul, and there's no amount of mocking of him or his company that can ever offset via discomfort the damage he's already done.

comment:
It's just a complete lie that EVERYONE believes themselves as proof against "radicalization" but they're worried about what Facebook shows others. Maybe the FB feed is biased to show such wording, because it silences and punishes free speech advocates who very much are fine with every world view among consenting adults. A massive number of us are perfectly fine with Facebook showing you (adults) anything within the adult sphere, and we have no interest in imposing our world view on others. Meanwhile there is clearly a large number of people who are truly afraid of information that contradicts their world view, and they react to it by seeking it's removal. Even when it's only an A to B conversation, people quickly block anyone who dares defy their world view. This is rationally irrefutable proof that such people aren't generally concerned about the radicalization of others, but rather they fear the uncertainty of questioning one's own fundamental axioms.

There most certainly isn't a near universal preference to "regulate other people's speech". The idea that this is "normal" is another blind belief pushed by the New Religion. By depicting this massive section of humanity (free speech advocates) as non-existent or "marginal" or "hypocritical", adherents of this new religion can convince the gullible ones to minimize the concept of free speech as "fringe".

comment: The expression of the idea that "conspiracy theories" are some great menace is in and of itself proof that the person expressing that apprehension is under the grasp of the "new religion" and it's objectively false assumptions. "Flat earth" is such a benign form of skepticism and so ridiculously easy to objectively prove false, the idea that, as an example of "conspiracy theory" it represents such a foreboding threat the AI most be deliberately created to avoid the subject is rather repulsive to anyone with a clear mind -- clear at least of these extreme religious beliefs. The term "conspiracy theory" has slowly morphed into a synonym of the term "blasphemy", and the new religion asserts itself when people internalize this unwittingly, without realizing its synonymous relation to the word blasphemy. It's truly scary stuff when obviously intelligent people like in this video are so obviously unaware...far more scary than any threat A.I. alone represents.

comment:
1) No, it is not true that Steve Jobs added a handle to the back of the iMac under the statement "Never trust a computer you can't throw out the window."

The quote "Never trust a computer you can't throw out the window" is attributed to Steve Wozniak, one of the co-founders of Apple. The quote is meant to be humorous, but it also reflects the idea that computers should be easy to use and understand.

The iMac was designed to be a user-friendly computer, and it did not need a handle to be carried. The iMac was also designed to be a modular computer, which means that it could be easily repaired or upgraded. This made it less likely that the iMac would need to be thrown out the window.

Steve Jobs did not add a handle to the back of the iMac, but he did make the iMac easy to carry and easy to repair.

-Bard

2) There is no evidence that Steve Jobs ever made this statement regarding the handle on the iMac. The quote is often attributed to Alan Kay, a computer scientist who worked on the development of Graphical User Interfaces (GUIs) in the 1960s and 1970s. The addition of the handle to the iMac was likely a practical design choice, rather than a reflection of Jobs' distrust of computers.

-Apo

3) ChatGPT 4 still thinking...
